Expectation1: Provide guidance and wisdom based on life experience
Situation1: A grandchild brings up a general question about navigating a new phase of their life.
Situation2: They set aside part of their routine to light a lamp and offer prayers at their home altar.
Story: This morning, as I prepared to light the lamp at our home altar, the familiar scent of sandalwood filled the air. My hands moved automatically, arranging the flowers and incense, my mind already reciting the prayers I have said every day for decades. Just as I reached for the matchbox, my granddaughter appeared at the doorway, her eyes wide and uncertain. “Amma, can I talk to you?” she asked, her voice trembling. She wanted to know how to face the changes coming with her new job in a distant city—how to be brave, how to stay true to herself. I saw the hope in her face, the trust that I would have the right words. But the clock ticked closer to the auspicious time for my puja, and I felt the weight of my faith pressing on me. If I delayed, I would miss the sacred moment. If I turned her away, I would fail her as a grandmother. My heart pulled in two directions, I stood frozen, torn between the call of my faith and the needs of my family, unsure which voice to answer first.
